Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: I stared at my computer screen, the spreadsheet blinking back at me. The quarterly report was due Monday, and I knew that if I didn’t finish it today, my teammate would be stuck waiting, their own work stalled. I could almost hear the unspoken expectation in our last meeting: “We’re counting on you.” But as I glanced at my phone, a reminder popped up—this weekend was the free vaccine clinic at the community center. I’d promised myself I’d volunteer, help out with the registration tables, do my part as a responsible citizen. The clinic only ran this weekend, and they were short on volunteers. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in. My colleagues needed me to meet the deadline, to keep the workflow smooth. My community needed me to step up, to help protect our neighbors’ health. I could feel the tension building in my chest, torn between the demands of my job and my responsibility as a citizen, knowing that whatever I chose, something important would be left undone.
